partial_orders.reason: Both edits perform an identical structural transformation on documentation strings: they move the 'required when state is present' information from a separate 'required' field into the description field using the same I(state) formatting pattern, and then set 'required: false'. This represents a uniform documentation formatting change applied to the same type of syntactic construct (YAML module documentation) with identical before→after patterns. The edits are part of a bulk refactoring to standardize how conditional requirements are documented across Ansible modules.

Both edits perform an identical structural transformation on documentation strings: they move the 'required when' condition from a separate 'required:' field into the description field itself, and then set 'required: false'. This is a uniform pattern substitution across the same type of syntactic construct (YAML documentation blocks in Ansible modules). The edits follow the exact same before→after pattern and target identical construct types, making them part of a single, contiguous refactoring operation.

Both edits perform identical structural changes to documentation format in the same file: changing 'required: true when state is 'present'' to 'Required when I(state) is 'present'' and adding 'required: false'. This is a uniform documentation formatting pattern being applied to multiple parameters in the same module.
